title: Passive stored XSS at Synthetics job result page (View resource)
vulnerability_information:
Hey team,

I've discovered a stored XSS at Synthetics job result page. There is a `View resource` link near every URL which was requested by a browser and this link `href` is the requested URL itself:
{F577804}

All the URLs, the browser interacted with, are saved into the database by a minion, when the job is finished. Below is a part of request, the minion sends when the job is finished:
```json
"entries": [
        {
          "pageref": "page_0",
          "startedDateTime": "2019-09-08T11:49:38.522+0000",
          "time": 324.3240000009537,
          "request": {
            "cookies": [],
            "headers": [],
            "headersSize": 744,
            "bodySize": 0,
            "method": "GET",
            "url": "http://google.com",
            "httpVersion": "http/1.1",
```
As you can see, the `url` parameter is inside, which control the href attribute of a vulnerable UI link, I've talked above.

Thus, attacker can emulate the minion work and result saving to plant a malicious `javascript:` URL there.

###Steps to reproduce
I've crafted a specific python-script, that emulates the minion work and saves a malicious payload into the job result. I know that PoCs which use hacker-controlled  *websites* are prohibited now, but I don't know whether the executable script PoCs are allowed. **If not, please let me know**, and I'll show you how to reproduce this with proxying the legitimate minion with BurpSuite.

1) Create some private location (it's not needed to run the minion itself), copy its `location_id`:
{F577814}
2) Create the scripted browser monitor executing at this private location and schedule it to be executed every 1 minute
3) Install python dependencies with `sudo pip install requests` at your linux workstation
4) Run the PoC-script {F577812} with `python malicious_minion.py {location_id}`, where `{location_id}` is the one copied at the step 1
5) Wait a little for the script work is finished and navigate to the link, the script finally printed 
6) Click the only request, "made by browser", the click at the `View resource` link
7) Make sure, the malicious JS is executed
{F577818}

I've set the severity in `Medium`, because the exploitation needs quite complicated user interaction (2 clicks), if you are not agree, please feel free to increase it :)

Also, an attacker can set absolutely any job metadata, and increase the chance of payload to be clicked by admin. For instance, he can set the job duration (and this malicious request's one in particular) to some big value, and the admin will see it when viewing "The longest queries".

##PoC video
{F577828}

## Impact

Stored XSS
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I've discovered a stored XSS at Synthetics job result page. There is a View resource link near every URL which was requested by a browser and this link href is the requested URL itself:

All the URLs, the browser interacted with, are saved into the database by a minion, when the job is finished. Below is a part of request, the minion sends when the job is finished:

"entries": [
        {
          "pageref": "page_0",
          "startedDateTime": "2019-09-08T11:49:38.522+0000",
          "time": 324.3240000009537,
          "request": {
            "cookies": [],
            "headers": [],
            "headersSize": 744,
            "bodySize": 0,
            "method": "GET",
            "url": "http://google.com",
            "httpVersion": "http/1.1",

As you can see, the url parameter is inside, which control the href attribute of a vulnerable UI link, I've talked above.

Thus, attacker can emulate the minion work and result saving to plant a malicious javascript: URL there.

Steps to reproduce

I've crafted a specific python-script, that emulates the minion work and saves a malicious payload into the job result. I know that PoCs which use hacker-controlled websites are prohibited now, but I don't know whether the executable script PoCs are allowed. If not, please let me know, and I'll show you how to reproduce this with proxying the legitimate minion with BurpSuite.

1) Create some private location (it's not needed to run the minion itself), copy its location_id:

2) Create the scripted browser monitor executing at this private location and schedule it to be executed every 1 minute
3) Install python dependencies with sudo pip install requests at your linux workstation
4) Run the PoC-script malicious_minion.py (F577812) with python malicious_minion.py {location_id}, where {location_id} is the one copied at the step 1
5) Wait a little for the script work is finished and navigate to the link, the script finally printed
6) Click the only request, "made by browser", the click at the View resource link
7) Make sure, the malicious JS is executed

I've set the severity in Medium, because the exploitation needs quite complicated user interaction (2 clicks), if you are not agree, please feel free to increase it :)

Also, an attacker can set absolutely any job metadata, and increase the chance of payload to be clicked by admin. For instance, he can set the job duration (and this malicious request's one in particular) to some big value, and the admin will see it when viewing "The longest queries".

PoC video

Impact

Stored XSS

activities.message: @skavans I was making the ticket and trying to set the severity, when I realized, I can't seem to access the XSS results without having the URL provided to me. It doesn't show up in the `Results` tab for me. Are you able to access it another way?
activities.markdown_message: @skavans I was making the ticket and trying to set the severity, when I realized, I can't seem to access the XSS results without having the URL provided to me. It doesn't show up in the Results tab for me. Are you able to access it another way?

activities.message:
Hey @jmcaleer,

I’m away of computer now so I can’t research this for you right now. But, my python script uses absolutely the same API as the legitimate minion does. Thus, I’m absolutely sure the infected page would be available through results, like any other job result. If you doubt, please give me few hours to make a proof for you. Actually, you can use no script at all to infect the job result. You can run legitimate minion, proxy it through burp, and create match-and-replace rule to replace all urls to JavaScript:alert(), so the job result will be saved in absolutely legitimate way, and it would be also available for viewing through results.
activities.markdown_message:

You can run legitimate minion, proxy it through burp, and create match-and-replace rule to replace all urls to JavaScript:alert(), so the job result will be saved in absolutely legitimate way, and it would be also available for viewing through results.

activities.message:
@skavans,

I talked to someone who understands the synthetics minions a lot better than I do. We think because your script still has the metadata from your job, the result I'm seeing must be orphaned as far as the UI is concerned.

activities.message: So, you agree that the infected result can be shown inside the results section if the job metadata is correct? Or I should to make a poc for you?

activities.message: Sorry @skavans, been super super busy. Also, as these are in the same UI (and there are probably more susceptible places), the developers will be reviewing the jobs' information (and hopefully other potentially user supplied places) and encoding all the outputs in the same fix. And I'll be marking the other ticket as a duplicate though providing a bonus.

activities.message:
Hey @skavans, I think we can cross out another one.

We're, uh, not super great about marking things as resolved. Sorry about that—we'll do better in the future.

Thank you for all your help! I don't know if we mentioned it, but your work spurred the business into hiring an entire team to work on these legacy code bases. With any luck, once the security issues are fixed, they can start to work on deprecating it for good.

activities.message:
Hey @ahamlin!

First of all, I'm so much excited to hear that I was helpful for you :)

By the way, I've found a bypass of your current fix. The fix you've implemented here is detecting whether the URL starts with a *scheme* (like `something:`) and then creating an active link only if the scheme is `http(s)`.  But, I've found that if I inject the TAB into a scheme, the scheme-detector doesn't consider it a scheme, but the browser does, however.

So, I use the following malicious URL to bypass the fix: `jav\tascript:alert()`. The Chrome and the Safari browsers execute such links without problems, but your detector passes them.
{F624535}

To reproduce this, please follow the reproduction steps from my initial report, but use this modified malicious minion script: {F624536}. I've modified it a little to inject the `\t` sign into a vulnerable URL.

You've correctly fixed #605845, so you can use the same approach here.
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @ahamlin!

First of all, I'm so much excited to hear that I was helpful for you :)

By the way, I've found a bypass of your current fix. The fix you've implemented here is detecting whether the URL starts with a scheme (like something:) and then creating an active link only if the scheme is http(s). But, I've found that if I inject the TAB into a scheme, the scheme-detector doesn't consider it a scheme, but the browser does, however.

So, I use the following malicious URL to bypass the fix: jav\tascript:alert(). The Chrome and the Safari browsers execute such links without problems, but your detector passes them.

To reproduce this, please follow the reproduction steps from my initial report, but use this modified malicious minion script: malicious_minion.py (F624536). I've modified it a little to inject the \t sign into a vulnerable URL.

You've correctly fixed #605845, so you can use the same approach here.
